title: Point Estimation Basics
description: A sample of 5 values is drawn: {2, 4, 6, 8, 10}. Calculate the sample mean and sample variance as point estimates of the population parameters.

title: Unbiased Estimators
description: Explain why we divide by (n-1) instead of n when calculating sample variance. What property does this give the estimator?
hints: Consider E[s²] when dividing by n vs. (n-1)
solution:
When we divide by (n-1) instead of n, the sample variance s² becomes an unbiased estimator of the population variance σ².

Dividing by n would give E[s²] < σ² (biased downward) because we use the sample mean instead of the true population mean.

Dividing by (n-1) corrects this bias, giving E[s²] = σ². The (n-1) is called Bessel's correction or degrees of freedom correction.

title: Confidence Interval for Mean
description: A sample of n=25 has mean x̄=50 and standard deviation s=10. Construct a 95% confidence interval for the population mean (use t-distribution with t₀.₀₂₅,₂₄ ≈ 2.064).
solution:
Standard error: SE = s/√n = 10/√25 = 10/5 = 2

Margin of error: ME = t × SE = 2.064 × 2 = 4.128

95% CI: 50 ± 4.128 = (45.872, 54.128)

We are 95% confident the true population mean is between 45.87 and 54.13.

title: Confidence Interval for Proportion
description: In a survey of 400 people, 240 support a policy. Construct a 95% confidence interval for the true proportion (use z=1.96).
solution:
Sample proportion: p̂ = 240/400 = 0.6

Standard error: SE = √[0.6(0.4)/400] = √[0.24/400] = √0.0006 ≈ 0.0245

Margin of error: ME = 1.96 × 0.0245 ≈ 0.048

95% CI: 0.6 ± 0.048 = (0.552, 0.648)

We are 95% confident the true proportion is between 55.2% and 64.8%.

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
description: Given n independent observations from a Poisson(λ) distribution, find the MLE of λ.
hints: Set derivative equal to zero and solve
solution:
Log-likelihood:
ℓ(λ) = Σ[xᵢ ln(λ) - λ - ln(xᵢ!)]
= ln(λ)Σxᵢ - nλ - Σln(xᵢ!)

Derivative:
dℓ/dλ = Σxᵢ/λ - n

Set to zero:
Σxᵢ/λ - n = 0
λ̂ = Σxᵢ/n = x̄

The MLE of λ is the sample mean.

title: MLE for Normal Distribution
description: For n independent observations from N(μ, σ²), find the MLEs of μ and σ².
hints: Take partial derivatives with respect to μ and σ²
solution:
Log-likelihood:
ℓ(μ,σ²) = -n/2 ln(2πσ²) - Σ(xᵢ-μ)²/(2σ²)

Partial derivative wrt μ:
∂ℓ/∂μ = Σ(xᵢ-μ)/σ² = 0
⟹ μ̂ = Σxᵢ/n = x̄

Partial derivative wrt σ²:
∂ℓ/∂σ² = -n/(2σ²) + Σ(xᵢ-μ)²/(2σ⁴) = 0
⟹ σ̂² = Σ(xᵢ-x̄)²/n

Note: σ̂² divides by n, not (n-1), so it's biased.

title: Method of Moments
description: For a Uniform(0, θ) distribution, find the method of moments estimator of θ.
hints: Set sample mean equal to population mean
solution:
For X ~ U(0,θ), E[X] = θ/2

Method of moments: set E[X] = x̄
θ/2 = x̄
θ̂ = 2x̄

The method of moments estimator is θ̂ = 2x̄

title: Sampling Distribution of Mean
description: If a population has mean μ=100 and variance σ²=400, what are the mean and standard deviation of the sampling distribution of x̄ based on n=25 observations?
solution:
Mean of sampling distribution: E[x̄] = μ = 100

Variance of sampling distribution: Var(x̄) = σ²/n = 400/25 = 16

Standard deviation (standard error): SD(x̄) = σ/√n = 20/5 = 4

title: Central Limit Theorem Application
description: A population has mean 50 and standard deviation 12. If we take samples of size 36, what is the probability that the sample mean exceeds 53?
hints: By CLT, x̄ is approximately normal with mean μ and SD σ/√n

title: Sample Size Determination
description: How large a sample is needed to estimate a population mean with 95% confidence and margin of error ±3, if σ=15?
solution:
Given: ME = 3, σ = 15, z = 1.96

From ME = z×σ/√n:
3 = 1.96×15/√n
√n = 1.96×15/3 = 9.8
n = (9.8)² = 96.04

Round up: n = 97 observations needed

title: Bias and Variance Tradeoff
description: Define bias and variance of an estimator. Explain the bias-variance tradeoff.
hints: Mean Squared Error relates to both
solution:
Bias of estimator θ̂:
Bias(θ̂) = E[θ̂] - θ
An unbiased estimator has E[θ̂] = θ

Variance of estimator:
Var(θ̂) = E[(θ̂ - E[θ̂])²]
Measures spread of estimates around their mean

Mean Squared Error:
MSE(θ̂) = E[(θ̂ - θ)²] = Bias²(θ̂) + Var(θ̂)

Bias-Variance Tradeoff: Sometimes accepting a small bias allows much lower variance, reducing overall MSE. This is why we sometimes prefer biased but consistent estimators with lower variance.

title: Confidence Level Interpretation
description: A 95% confidence interval for μ is (47, 53). Explain what this means and what it does NOT mean.
solution:
CORRECT interpretation:
If we repeated this sampling process many times, 95% of the confidence intervals constructed would contain the true parameter μ.

INCORRECT interpretations:
❌ There is a 95% probability that μ is in (47, 53)
❌ 95% of the data falls in (47, 53)
❌ The probability that μ = 50 is 95%

The interval (47, 53) either contains μ or it doesn't (it's not random). The 95% refers to our confidence in the method, not this particular interval.

title: Comparing Estimators
description: Two estimators of θ have E[θ̂₁] = θ, Var(θ̂₁) = 10 and E[θ̂₂] = θ + 0.5, Var(θ̂₂) = 2. Which is better in terms of MSE?
solution:
For θ̂₁:
Bias = E[θ̂₁] - θ = 0
MSE(θ̂₁) = 0² + 10 = 10

For θ̂₂:
Bias = E[θ̂₂] - θ = 0.5
MSE(θ̂₂) = (0.5)² + 2 = 0.25 + 2 = 2.25

θ̂₂ has lower MSE (2.25 < 10), so it's better despite being biased. The small bias is outweighed by much lower variance.

title: Standard Error
description: Explain the difference between standard deviation and standard error. How does sample size affect each?
solution:
Standard Deviation (SD):
- Measures variability in the population or sample
- SD = σ or s
- Does not change with sample size (population SD is fixed)

Standard Error (SE):
- Measures precision of a sample statistic (like x̄)
- SE = σ/√n
- Decreases as sample size increases
- SE → 0 as n → ∞

Example: If σ = 20 and n = 100:
SD = 20 (unchanged)
SE = 20/√100 = 2

Larger samples give more precise estimates (smaller SE) but don't change population variability (SD).

title: Bootstrapping Concept
description: Explain the basic idea of bootstrap resampling and when it might be useful.
hints: Think about resampling from the sample itself
Consider when parametric assumptions are questionable
solution:
Bootstrap resampling:
1. Take a sample of size n from population
2. Repeatedly resample (with replacement) from this sample
3. Calculate the statistic of interest for each resample
4. Use the distribution of these statistics to estimate properties

When useful:
- Unknown or complex sampling distribution
- Small samples where CLT may not apply
- Non-standard statistics (median, trimmed mean, etc.)
- Estimating confidence intervals without parametric assumptions

Example: From original sample {2,5,7,9}, we might create bootstrap samples like {2,2,7,9}, {5,7,7,9}, {2,5,5,9}, etc., calculate x̄ for each, and use these to estimate SE(x̄) and construct CIs.

title: Fisher Information
description: For a Bernoulli(p) distribution, the Fisher information is I(p) = 1/(p(1-p)). What does this tell us about the precision of estimation for different values of p?
hints: Higher Fisher information means more information about the parameter
solution:
Fisher information I(p) = 1/(p(1-p))

The Cramér-Rao lower bound states that Var(p̂) ≥ 1/(n×I(p)) = p(1-p)/n

At p = 0.5:
I(0.5) = 1/(0.5×0.5) = 4
Minimum variance = 0.25/n

At p = 0.1:
I(0.1) = 1/(0.1×0.9) = 11.11
Minimum variance = 0.09/n

Counter-intuitively, estimation is most difficult (lowest information) when p = 0.5, and easier when p is near 0 or 1. This is because extreme probabilities provide more information per observation about which category you're in.
